A BARN FOR THE BARNSTORMERS

I often laugh when I perceive the
a
efforts of some people to attain
old,
na-r-Iced degree of culture. That
preold story of the two negroes
sents itself to me very startlingly
(supat times—the two who were
posedly) discussing their sc-hool
work together, when one asked the
other: "Isya tlidja Greek?" To
think that before reaching a degree
of even passing knowledge concerning their own language—one which
constituted an essential in their everyday lives,-they had been prying
deeply. into a language and a literature which, no doubt, would never
be of any practical value at all!
Through a bit of work which I
do occasionally I am put in a position to survey the titles of numerous dissertations; these dissertations
each representing the strenuous efforts of some energetic person who
has strived (usually with success) to
earn a higher degree. Some of the
titles:--in fact,- justly speaking,.a
great many of them—show promises
of being distinctly worthwhile; but
again, some of them are absolutely
ridieulous. Frifi-ristance-,-Some-person very kindly worked industriously in order to enlighten mankind at
great length oil the pronunciation of
the vowel "a" in Chaucer. And in
the meantime some people are starving physically, and some others are
starving intellectually. So if financial charity is impossible, it seems
to me that great and unselfish work
might have been done by some people towards charitably enlightening

Sailors Beg
Master Mariner
for Favorite
Pipe Tobacco
Malden, Mass,
March 10, 1928
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Dear Sirs:
I have been a Master Mariner for
many years, and as a general rule all
seafaring men smoke a pipe. I have
tried about all the different brands of
tobacco on the market,and in my estimation, there is not one make of tobacco that will compare with Edgeworth Slice for a good,cool,long smoke.
Sailors would come to me and say
"Capt., be sure to put in a good supply of Edgeworth when you till up the
canteen." That speaks for what the
average sailor thinks of Edgeworth.
I retired from the sea six years ago,
and the largest grocery dealers in
Boston keep me supplied with this
wonderful smoke. I take great pleasure
in boosting it to my friends.
Very truly yours,
(signed) Capt. C. E. Kenney

Through a bit of work which I

Sailors Beg
Master Mariner
for Favorite
Pipe Tobacco
Malden, Mass,
March 10, 1928
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Dear Sirs:
I have been a Master Mariner for
many years, and as a general rule all
seafaring men smoke a pipe. I have
tried about all the different brands of
tobacco on the market,and in my estimation, there is not one make of tobacco that will compare with Edgeworth Slice for a good,cool,long smoke.
Sailors would come to me and say
"Capt., be sure to put in a good supply of Edgeworth when you till up the
canteen." That speaks for what the
average sailor thinks of Edgeworth.
I retired from the sea six years ago,
and the largest grocery dealers in
Boston keep me supplied with this
wonderful smoke. I take great pleasure
in boosting it to my friends.
Very truly yours,
(signed) Capt. C. E. Kenney
